Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent infringed the applicant's trademark 'High Times' and passed off its business as associated with the applicant
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavit evidence was used; respondent did not participate
Decision_Outcome: Respondent found to have infringed the trademark and engaged in passing off; insufficient evidence of depreciation of goodwill
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to prove likelihood of confusion and misrepresentation
Credibility_Factor: Respondent did not appear or respond, affecting assessment of credibility
Legal_Rule: Confusion between trademarks constitutes infringement and passing off under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of 'High Times' leading to likely customer confusion
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld on infringement and passing off
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Proceedings conducted via affidavit; respondent had opportunity but chose not to participate
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of 'High Times' on storefront, similarity in products and target market, likelihood of confusion
Legal_Framework: Statutory framework under the Trade-marks Act and common law principles of passing off
Applicant_Challenge: Proving unauthorized use, goodwill, and likelihood of confusion
Court_Result: $25,000 in damages and $30,000 in costs awarded to applicant; injunction issued
Defendant_Response: No response or appearance by respondent
Outcome: Damages and costs awarded; permanent injunction granted
Claimant_Status: Registered owner of the trademark 'High Times'
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of trademark infringement and passing off based on unauthorized use
Applicable_Process: Federal Court civil proceeding on affidavits
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Final judgment rendered; no pending relief
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under the Trade-marks Act
Governing_Rule: Trade-marks Act and equitable principles of passing off
